data.title: Amazon says 'appropriate' executive available after U.S. House panel calls on CEO Bezos to testify
data.text: Amazon.com Inc  said on Friday it would make the "appropriate" executive available to the U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee to testify about allegations related to how the company uses third-party sellers' data.

data.title: Amazon declines to commit to Jeff Bezos testimony in Congress
data.text: Earlier this month, members of the House Judiciary Committee accused Amazon of lying to Congress over its private label strategy.

data.title: Amazon Makes No Promises on Bezos Testimony
data.text: The company said it would be happy to send someone to testify. But it never mentions Jeff Bezos.

data.title: Indexes Reverse Higher; Dow, Nasdaq Bounce Off Key Support Levels (May 15)
data.text: The bulls regained control Thursday after two days of sharp declines for the major stock indexes.

data.title: Amazon And Walmart Up The Stakes As Online Grocery Shopping Booms
data.text: Soaring online grocery demand is pitting Amazon vs. Walmart in the epic shift toward online sales, but will the shift hold in a post-coronavirus world?

data.title: Amazon Stock Is Still a Must-Own for Growth Investors
data.text:
Here are several key reasons why Amazon stock is arguably a safer bet than it was before the coronavirus crisis.

data.title: Bill Miller Says Amazon Could Double in Three Years
data.text: Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) has been one of the best-performing stocks in 2020. Amid the market volatility and recession fears, shares of this e-commerce behemoth have gained a staggering 25%.

data.title: Amazon Stock Benefits If AWS Is Spun Off
data.text: Months ago, news reports surfaced that the Federal Trade Commission would begin an examination of Amazon’s business practices.

data.title: Amazon insists sharing data on coronavirus cases isn't useful
data.text: Amazon is famed for its data-driven approach to management and decision-making. It measures worker "rates" to determine productivity; collected extensive local data as part of its search for a second headquarters; takes pains to predict what customers want next based on prior purchases; and frequently issues press releases dense with random stats about product sales. But when it comes to the total number of coronavirus cases in its warehouses, Amazon's view is, as one executive recently put it, that information isn't "particularly useful."

data.title: This breakdown of retail sales data shows why Amazon is leading the stock market
data.text: Retail sales plunged in April, but one area saw a jump.

data.title: Two more Amazon worker deaths push its coronavirus toll to seven
data.text: Two Amazon warehouse workers in Indiana have reportedly died of the coronavirus, pushing the company’s death toll to at least seven. The e-commerce giant learned Wednesday that COVID-19 had killed an employee at its facility in Jeffersonville, near Louisville, Kentucky, according to local CBS affiliate WLKY.

data.title: 3 No-Brainer Retail Stocks to Buy Now
data.text: Though the retail space is an utter mess due to the coronavirus, these three businesses stand out for all the right reasons.

data.title: Amazon Stock Is Making the Case for Death Star Status
data.text: Amazon.com (NASDAQ: AMZN) has more than earned the nickname the “Death Star” on Wall Street as its stock has hit all-time highs during the COVID-19 pandemic.

data.title: Amazon files lawsuit over 'widespread tech support fraud'
data.text: Amazon is accusing two companies of "widespread tech support fraud" targeting users of its Alexa virtual assistant and smart speakers.

data.title: The seventh Amazon worker has died from COVID-19, and employees are scared
data.text:
At least 800 Amazon warehouse workers have tested positive for COVID-19.
Since the pandemic began its spread around the United States, Amazon has become something of a necessity for millions of Americans under lockdown.

data.title: Amazon To Manufacture Face Shields And Sell Them At Cost
data.text: Over the next few weeks, Amazon Inc. (NASDAQ: AMZN) will be selling reusable face shields at cost, first to medical professionals and later to all customers.
